Idiom (Kölsch): Et hät noch immer joot jejange.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause; perfect tense structure with auxiliary 'hät' and past participle 'jejange'.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Things tend to turn out well in the end; optimistic resignation.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Everything will be fine in the end.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common saying from Cologne reflecting Rhineland optimism and humor.
First Example Sentence: Mach der kei Sorje, et hät noch immer joot jejange.
Second Example Sentence: D’r Pitter hät widder alles verjess, ävver et hät noch immer joot jejange.
Third Example Sentence: Selvs wann et schief jitt, säät mer he: et hät noch immer joot jejange.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause; simple present tense repetition for emphasis.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: What’s gone is gone; no use regretting the past.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: You can’t get back what’s lost.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional Rhineland expression promoting emotional resilience.
First Example Sentence: Häs de dä Zettel verlore? Wat fott es, es fott.
Second Example Sentence: Kein Jroll, Jung – wat fott es, es fott.
Third Example Sentence: Do hätt dä de Fläsch jefalle losse – wat fott es, es fott.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause; present tense copula structure.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Everyone is unique; people have their quirks.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Carnival saying emphasizing individuality and acceptance.
First Example Sentence: He drengk met de Hand, dat es halt su – jede Jeck es anders.
Second Example Sentence: Ich verstonn dä nit, ävver jede Jeck es anders.
Third Example Sentence: Mir laache d’rövver, weil jede Jeck es anders.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause with repetition of verb 'kütt' (comes).
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: It is what it is; acceptance of circumstances.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reflects Rhineland pragmatism and acceptance of fate.
First Example Sentence: Mir könne nix dran ändere – et kütt wie et kütt.
Second Example Sentence: He hät dat verlore, ävver et kütt wie et kütt.
Third Example Sentence: Wann dä Zoch nit kütt, dann kütt dä nächste – et kütt wie et kütt.

Idiom (Kölsch): Do moß mer durch, wie d’r Kall durch d’r Maat.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Comparative clause with simile; prepositional phrase.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: You just have to get through it; persevere despite hardship.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: You must endure and push through.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rural and folk-based expression from Cologne region.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Kölsch): [do mɔs mɛʁ dʏʁç viː də kɑl dʏʁç də maːt]
First Example Sentence: D’r Exame es schwer, ävver do moß mer durch, wie d’r Kall durch d’r Maat.
Second Example Sentence: Et regnet wie d’r Zoch, ävver do moß mer durch, wie d’r Kall durch d’r Maat.
Third Example Sentence: Wenn et komplizeet weed, do moß mer durch, wie d’r Kall durch d’r Maat.

Idiom (Kölsch): Mer soll de Dagg nit vör d’r Ovend lobe.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Subordinate clause with negation; present tense modal structure.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Don’t celebrate too early; wait for the result.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Don’t count your chickens before they hatch.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional proverb found across German dialects; popular in Cologne.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Kölsch): [mɛʁ zɔl də dak nɪt føː dəʁ oːvənt loːbə]
First Example Sentence: Dä Match es nit vöörbei, mer soll de Dagg nit vör d’r Ovend lobe.
Second Example Sentence: Et jitt noch vill ze dunn, mer soll de Dagg nit vör d’r Ovend lobe.
Third Example Sentence: Ich freu mich, ävver mer soll de Dagg nit vör d’r Ovend lobe.

Idiom (Kölsch): Do hät dä Hund de Wursch jejange.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Past perfect clause with dative subject and object phrase.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: It’s too late; something valuable has been lost or missed.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rural saying from the Rhineland reflecting humor and resignation.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Kölsch): [do hɛt də hʊnt də vʊʁʃ jəjɑŋə]
First Example Sentence: Hätts de nit gezögert, dann hätt dä Hund de Wursch nit jejange.
Second Example Sentence: He hät nix jemaat – do hät dä Hund de Wursch jejange.
Third Example Sentence: Mer hätt et schneller maache müsse, jetz hät dä Hund de Wursch jejange.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Acceptance of reality; a statement of fact.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Core expression of Rhineland mentality; part of ‘Kölsche Grundgesetz’.
First Example Sentence: Et es wie et es, do könne mer nix draan ändere.
Second Example Sentence: He hät dä Job nit krieje, ävver et es wie et es.
Third Example Sentence: Et es wie et es, säät d’r Opa immer.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Imperative phrase; second person singular form.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Let’s go! / Go ahead!; an expression of motivation or urgency.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Commonly used in Cologne’s everyday speech and football culture.
First Example Sentence: Loss jonn, dä Bus kütt jleich!
Third Example Sentence: Loss jonn, Jung, zeig wat de kanns!

Idiom (Kölsch): Et es noch kei Meister vom Himmel jefalle.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Complex clause with perfect participle and negation.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Nobody is perfect from the start; mastery takes time.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: German-wide proverb, popularized in Rhineland dialects.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Kölsch): [ɛt ɛs nɔx kaɪ maɪstɐ fɔm hɪməl jəfalə]
First Example Sentence: Mach dir kei Sorje, et es noch kei Meister vom Himmel jefalle.
Second Example Sentence: Beim Koche weed mer besser – et es noch kei Meister vom Himmel jefalle.
Third Example Sentence: Et jitt Übung, däät dä Lehrer säje, et es noch kei Meister vom Himmel jefalle.
